Award.AwardTitle: The Chronology of Warfare In The Huaura Valley, Central Coast of Peru

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the National Science Foundation, Dr. Margaret Brown Vega and colleagues from the U.S. and Perú (Proyecto Awqa Pacha) will conduct archaeological research in the Huaura Valley on the Central Coast of Perú. Archaeologists have long sought to identify the causes and long-term consequences of war. Through a program of systematic survey and radiocarbon dating of fortifications, Proyecto Awqa Pacha seeks to contribute to these efforts. The project will establish the timing of fortification in the Huaura Valley during the first millennium BC, a span of time during which monumental defensive architecture was first built in the Central Andes. This span of time (the Early Horizon, ca. 900-200 BC, and subsequent transitional period, ca. 200 BC-AD 200) encompassed unprecedented regional interaction, followed by a breakdown of regional relationships, and subsequent reconfigurations that culminated in new regional polities. This is an ideal region for examining the role that war plays in such social changes.

Focused studies of fortifications establish the timing and spatial patterning of conflict, and permit examination of aggressive and cooperative interactions between groups living in a climate of war readiness. Prior research in the region suggests multiple pulses of fort construction. Relative chronologies prove too coarse to assess the contemporaneity, and changing distribution, of fortifications over time. Fieldwork will focus on acquiring samples for building a more refined chronological sequence of early fortifications using Accelerator Mass Spectrometry. These data will permit spatial analysis of contemporary fortifications to better understand group conflict throughout this millennium. Specifically, these data will be used to test for intravalley or intervalley conflict.

The research has multiple intellectual merits. A refined model for the development of fortifications in the Huaura Valley will enable other scholars to reconsider the broader regional phenomena of this early period of warfare on the Peruvian coast. Because many early fortifications are reused by later people, understanding this early period of warfare is critical to analyzing subsequent periods of culture change. The corpus of dates produced by this research will be a significant contribution to the radiocarbon database for the Central Andes. Beyond the Central Andes, the Huaura Valley case study will contribute new data and a more refined approach to assessing different scales of group conflict. Broadly, this assessment is fundamental for building, from archaeological data, adequate explanations of the causes and consequences of warfare. These data hold great potential for examining human-environment interactions, and assessing the relationship between climate records and cultural processes.

The broader impacts of the research are in training students and fostering international collaboration. Undergraduate students from the U.S.A. and Perú will be trained in data management, field acquisition of data, and analytical methods through hands on experience and individualized teaching. They will also participate directly as part of an international scholarly collaboration. Project results will be presented collaboratively and widely shared with scholars and the public via both print and digital mediums. The project's database will be accessible to other scholars in the future for both teaching and research activities.

Research Problem and Activities

How and why warfare first emerges among human societies, and the consequences of that process, has long been of interest to social scientists. At the same time, identification of the evidence of that process, such as the building of fortifications for defense, has been under-reported. Archaeology is uniquely positioned to identify this evidence, and provide empirical data with which to evaluate prior assertions about war among human societies. Funds were requested to assemble refined information on where, and when, warfare was occurring over the course of a millennium in one valley of the coast of Perú. 

The goal of this project, Proyecto Awqa Pacha, is to ultimately explain the emergence and subsequent cycles of warfare in the coastal regions of Perú, and to understand the impact of warfare on cultural developments. Specifically, systematic targeted survey and radiocarbon dating of fortifications in the Huaura Valley provide basic building blocks of knowledge on warfare, and set up this region as a case study to examine the long-term impacts of war. An analysis of the origins and development of fortifications in this region allows for a more sophisticated interpretation of how large-scale warfare unfolds for the first time, and what its ramifications are over the long-term. Who built and used fortifications in ancient societies, and whether groups allied themselves against external threats or battled each other, are fundamental questions that must be addressed before examining larger theoretical questions, such as the emergence for the first time of state-level societies in human history.

More than 30 fortified sites have been documented in the Huaura Valley by Proyecto Awqa Pacha, nearly all of them with early components dating to the Late Formative Period (ca. 1000-200 BC) and Early Intermediate Period (ca. 200 BC-AD 500). During the funded research period, the project documented additional fortifications, and assembled detailed data on architecture and artifacts present on the surface of these sites. Some artifacts recovered from excavations inform on the relationship between conflict, the exchange, and the development of leadership. Most importantly, the project accomplished the main funded objective, which was to excavate small test units at a group of early fortifications to obtain organic material for Accelerator Mass Spectrometry (AMS) radiocarbon dating. 57 small-scale excavations were carried out at 27 fortifications that were hypothesized to have early components, yielding 302 samples of organic material from secure contexts. Of these samples, 55 have been analyzed at the University of Arizona AMS Radiocarbon Laboratory, producing the largest suite of dates for fortified sites in the region. These data allow for a more fine-grained analysis of when these early forts were in use, and permit an examination of contemporaneous fortifications. These analyses are currently underway.

Intellectual Merit and Broader Impacts

The identification of fortifications, an important indicator of warfare, corrects the under-reporting of evidence for conflict in the ancient past. This has direct bearing on how warfare is interpreted in the context of social and political developments, particularly during formative periods. Building a refined model for the emergence and development of fortifications in the Huaura Valley provides data with which to reconsider the broader regional phenomena of this early period of warfare on the Peruvian coast, a center of early state formation.
